QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many public servants within the Department of the Treasury and any other department have access to the quarterly figures compiled by the Joint Economic Forecasting Group.
(2) What are the positions of such people within the Public Service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Joint Economic Forecasting Group (JEFG) comprises officers from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Reserve Bank of Australia, the Department of Finance, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, Treasury and the Treasurer's economic consultant. Distribution of the report and associated figures compiled by JEFG is confined to those officers directly involved in the work of the Group and to senior officers of the participating institutions.

Within the Australian Bureau of Statistics four senior officers within the Economic Accounts Division and Statistical and User Services Division have access to JEFG reports. A further three persons in these areas have partial access to the reports on a need-to-know basis.

Within the Reserve Bank, the Governor, Deputy Governor and three senior members of the Research Department have access to the JEFG report. Other members of the Research Department involved in the work of the Group have partial access to the report and associated figuring on a need-to-know basis.

Within the Department of Finance, the Secretary, Deputy Secretaries and five senior officers in the General Expenditure Division have access to the JEFG report. Two other officers have access to associated figures on a need-to-know basis.

Within the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Secretary, a Deputy Secretary and three senior officers and two other staff in the Economic and Social Policy Division have access to the JEFG report. Two other senior officers have partial access on a need to know basis.

Within the Department of Treasury, the Secretary, the Deputy Secretaries, First Assistant Secretaries and ten other senior officers have access to the JEFG report. The staff of the Forecasting Unit, presently numbering eight persons, also have access to the report and associated figures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Australian owned or based companies have holdings in South Africa of $A1m or more.
(2) What South African owned or based companies have holdings in Australia of $A1m or more.
(3) What South African companies have invested in Australia in the last 5 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) For legal and commercial confidentiality reasons, it is not possible to respond to these questions in terms of the particular companies involved. In the course of the administration of the Government's foreign investment policy, the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) has access to information relating to proposed investments in Australia by South African companies but that information is provided in confidence and it has been longstanding Government practice not to disclose details of proposals or of the parties to proposals, except in special circumstances and where the parties' consent is first obtained. In these special cases, the Treasurer issues a press release on the particular proposal. Companies directly owned by South African interests which proposed to invest in Australia in the past five years and in respect of which press releases have been issued are:
Anglo American Group
RUC Mining Contracting Pty Ltd
Freight Services Holdings Ltd
Pick'n Pay Ltd

The Australian Bureau of Statistics also collects information on investment flows to and from South Africa. The secrecy provisions of the Census and Statistics Act prevent release by the ABS of information identifying particular companies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Australian Bureau of Statistics currently conducting a survey into household energy use; if so:
(a) what matters are involved in the survey;
(b) what facts have as yet been made known, in relation to its survey findings; and
(c) what factors led to the decision to undertake the enquiry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. Notice of the proposal by the Australian Bureau of Statistics to conduct a Household Energy Survey during 1985-86 was tabled in the Senate on 28 March 1985 (Proposal No. 2), and collection of relevant information commenced in mid-June 1985.

(a) The survey seeks data from 18,000 households throughout Australia on the use of energy-using domestic appliances, consumption of electricity and reticulated gas, sources of energy, insulation of dwellings, size of household and family structure, household income (in broad ranges), seasonality in energy consumption and fuel substitution.
(b) No statistical information has yet been released from the survey. It is expected that the ABS will commence publishing results in June 1987.

(c) The survey has been designed to meet the requirements of the Commonwealth Department of Resources and Energy and State energy authorities and utilities for information to assist in policy formulation and evaluation, with specific reference to forecasting of energy demand and assessment of fuel substitution programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1985 (Hansard, Page 181) Senator Jack Evans asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the collection of information on foreign ownership and control of major assets in Australia. The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: A range of information concerning foreign ownership and control in the Australian economy is already being collected and published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Bureau has published estimates of foreign ownership and control in the mining and resource processing industries and in manufacturing. In addition, it plans to produce estimates of foreign ownership and control of rural land and of foreign participation in financial corporations.

The information already collected and published and that in prospect should provide comprehensive and comparative data on the foreign ownership and control of industries in Australia. Information regarding the ownership and control of banks by foreign interests has been published. Any proposals, directly or indirectly, by such banks to extend foreign ownership and control of Australian assets will be examined in the usual way under Australian foreign investment policy.
